Oleh karena itu, janganlah sekali-kali manusia tertipu oleh kesenangan hidup di dunia dan segala kenikmatan yang ada padanya, sehingga mereka berusaha dan menghabiskan seluruh waktu yang ada untuk memperoleh dan menikmati kesenangan-kesenangan duniawi. Akibatnya, tidak ada waktu lagi untuk beribadah kepada Allah, serta mengerjakan kebajikan dan amal saleh. Padahal kehidupan akhirat itulah kehidupan yang sebenarnya, kehidupan yang kekal dan lebih baik.

Demikian pula Allah memperingatkan manusia akan tipu daya setan, yang selalu mencari-cari kesempatan untuk memperdaya manusia. Setan itu menjadikan kehidupan dunia itu indah dalam pandangan matanya, sehingga mereka lupa kepada tugas yang dipikulkan Allah kepada mereka sebagai khalifatullah fil ardh (makhluk yang diberi-Nya tugas memakmurkan bumi).
text.34:
Pada ayat ini, Allah menerangkan lima perkara gaib yang hanya Dia yang mengetahuinya, yaitu:

1. Hanya Allah yang mengetahui kapan datangnya Hari Kiamat. Tidak ada satu makhluk pun yang mengetahui meskipun itu malaikat, padahal malaikat adalah makhluk yang paling dekat dengan-Nya. Hal ini juga tidak diketahui oleh para nabi yang diutus.

Tidak ada (seorang pun) yang dapat menjelaskan waktu terjadinya selain Dia. (al-A'raf/7: 187) 

2. Hanya Allah yang menurunkan hujan. Dia yang menetapkan kapan, dimana, dan berapa banyak kadar air yang akan dicurahkan-Nya. Ketetapan ini tidak seorang pun yang dapat mengetahuinya. 

3. Hanya Allah yang dapat mengetahui dengan pasti apa yang ada dalam kandungan seorang perempuan, apakah cacat atau sempurna, dan kapan ia akan dilahirkan.

4. Hanya Dia pula yang mengetahui dengan pasti apa yang akan dikerjakan oleh seseorang esok harinya. Sekalipun manusia dapat merencanakan apa yang akan dikerjakannya itu, namun semuanya itu hanyalah bersifat rencana saja. Jika Allah menghendaki, pekerjaan itu akan terlaksana. Akan tetapi, jika Ia tidak menghendaki, tidak sukar bagi-Nya untuk menghalangi terlaksananya.

5. Seseorang tidak mengetahui di mana ia akan meninggal dunia nanti. Apakah di daratan, di lautan, ataupun di udara. Apakah di negeri ini, atau di negeri yang lain. Hanya Allah saja yang dapat mengetahuinya dengan pasti.

Diriwayatkan dari Ibnu Mundzir dari 'Ikrimah bahwa seorang laki-laki bernama al-Waris bin 'Amr bin harisah datang kepada Nabi saw, ia bertanya, "Ya Muhammad, kapan akan datang hari Kiamat? Bumi kita telah kering, kapan akan menjadi subur? Sesungguhnya aku meninggalkan istriku dalam keadaan hamil, kapan ia akan melahirkan? Aku mengetahui apa yang aku kerjakan sekarang, maka apakah yang akan aku kerjakan esok harinya? Aku mengetahui tempat aku dilahirkan, maka di tempat manakah aku akan meninggal? Sebagai jawabannya, turunlah ayat ini.

Diriwayatkan oleh al-Bukhari dan Muslim dari Ibnu 'Umar bahwa Rasulullah saw bersabda:

Kunci masalah yang gaib itu ada lima, "Sesungguhnya hanya pada Allah sajalah pengetahuan tentang Hari Kiamat. Dialah yang menurunkan hujan, Dia mengetahui apa yang dalam rahim, seseorang tidak mengetahui apa yang akan dikerjakannya esok harinya, dan ia juga tidak mengetahui di bumi mana ia akan meninggal dunia. Sesungguhnya Allah Maha Mengetahui lagi Maha Penyayang." (Riwayat al-Bukhari dan Muslim dari Ibnu 'Umar)

en.name: Luqman
en.source: Aplikasi Quran Kementrian Agama Republik Indonesia

text.1: This Surah Luqman begins with the letters of the Arabic alphabet "Alif Lam Mim". For further explanation of Alif Lam Mim, see volume I.
text.2: This verse explains that the verses of the Qur'an are arranged neatly and meticulously, with a high literary style, and with a noble and sublime purpose for those who follow its guidance. There are no defects, flaws, or shortcomings in it, not even the slightest. Nor is there any contradiction between its verses. Its commands are easily carried out by anyone, in any situation and wherever they may be.
text.3:
These verses affirm that the verses of the Al-Qur'an contain guidance for humanity in navigating all aspects of life in this world, leading and guiding them to achieve happiness in the afterlife.

If one opens the pages of history from ancient times to the present, one will conclude that with the sending of the Prophet Muhammad by Allah, bringing the Al-Qur'an containing the core messages he carried, the doors of goodness were opened for the entire universe. With this, the development of knowledge in all its branches also increased.

Even though there were already high cultures as a result of human thought in the period before this, such as the cultures of ancient Egypt, Babylon, Greece, and so on, all of that did not yet have strong and solid foundations to achieve further and more perfect human development in the future.

In the field of human life and existence, the Al-Qur'an provides guidance so that humans maintain a balance between physical and spiritual life, as well as a balance in achieving worldly and *ukhrawi* (hereafter) life. Likewise, in social and state life, what is *halal* (permissible) and good to eat may be eaten, and what is not good should not be eaten. There are also guidelines on how to speak and associate well, and so on. The Al-Qur'an provides guidance and rules, then humans process and adapt themselves to the surrounding nature based on that guidance and rules, which is the best and most appropriate to implement, and which must be avoided and abandoned. People who think, contemplate, process, and practice the guidance of the Al-Qur'an in the best possible way are " *muhsin* " (those who do good).
text.4:
In these verses, it is mentioned that among the signs of the *muhsin* (those who do good) are:

1. Always performing the five daily prayers that are obligated upon them at each appointed time. They always strive to perform the prayers in the best possible way, complete with their pillars and conditions.

2. Always paying *zakat* if its obligatory conditions have been met. They are certain that paying *zakat* is an obligation because in their wealth there is a right belonging to others that must be promptly given.

3. Believing that there is life after death, which is the Hereafter. In the life of the Hereafter, every human being will receive perfect justice from Allah. Good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise, and evil deeds will be punished with the torment of Hell.
text.5: Those who possess the signs and characteristics mentioned in the previous verses are those who follow the guidance of their Lord. They attain success because they obtain good and pleasing results after working and striving to follow the guidance of the Qur'an. A person who performs righteous deeds will attain success in this world and in the hereafter, and this is obtained by performing good deeds.
text.6:
This verse explains that among humans, there are those who disregard beneficial words that can increase one's faith in religion and improve their character. They prefer to utter useless words, convey superstitions, tales of the past, and meaningless jokes. An example of this is what Nadhar bin Haris did, by buying Persian books containing stories, then mocking them to the Quraysh people. If necessary, they would hire singers to perform for the public. The content of the songs and their voices were crafted in such a way as to stimulate listeners to commit forbidden acts and further distance them from religion.

It is narrated from Nafi', who said, "I was walking with 'Abdullah bin 'Umar on a journey when we heard the sound of a flute. 'Abdullah then put his fingers in his ears to avoid hearing the sound of the flute and he diverted to another road. Then he said, 'Nafi', can you still hear the sound?' I replied, 'No.' Then he took his fingers out of his ears and said, 'This is how I saw the Messenger of Allah (saw) do when he heard such a sound.'"

In another narration from 'Abdurrahman bin 'Auf, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"I am forbidden (from listening to) two kinds of sounds (noises) that are meaningless and cause evil deeds, namely the sound of distracting songs and the flutes of Satan, and (secondly) the sound when afflicted by calamity, namely slapping the face, tearing clothes, and the songs of Satan." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi)

According to Ibn Mas'ud, what is meant by the phrase *lahw al-hadis* in this verse is singing, because it can cause hypocrisy in the heart. Some scholars say that all sounds, words, songs, and noises that can damage obedience to Allah and encourage listeners to commit forbidden acts are called *lahw al-hadis*.

From the verse and hadiths above, it can be concluded that what is prohibited is listening to songs that can arouse lust and lead to adultery, such as songs containing vulgar words. This also includes songs or music that cause listeners to commit forbidden acts, such as drinking khamar and so on.

Listening to songs or music that aims to relax the mind during rest or holidays is not prohibited. It is even encouraged to listen to it if the song or music has a good meaning, increases faith, improves character, and increases the spirit of work and struggle.

Qusyairi said, "The tambourine was played in front of the Prophet (saw) when he entered the city of Medina, then Abu Bakar wanted to stop it, but the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, 'Let them play the tambourine, O Abu Bakar, so that the Jews know that our religion is not narrow.' They played the tambourine accompanied by songs and poems, among the verses of which read: " *Nahnu banatun Najjar, habbadha Muhammadun min jar* " (We are the women of Bani Najjar, how fortunate we are if Muhammad becomes our neighbor)."

In this verse, Allah explains the consequences of hearing and playing forbidden songs, music, and words. They will receive a humiliating torment on the Day of Judgment as a result of their actions of disregarding the truth and choosing falsehood, and exchanging guidance for sin.
text.7:
In this verse, Allah explains the characteristics of those who exchange the books of Allah for useless tales. When the verses of Allah are recited to them, they turn their backs with an arrogant and haughty attitude, as if they did not hear them because their ears have been blocked and are deaf.

In another verse, Allah says:

Say, "It is, for those who believe, a guidance and cure. And those who do not believe - in their ears is deafness, and it is upon them blindness. (Fushshilat/41: 44)

Because of that action, they will receive a painful punishment in the Hereafter. That is as a recompense for their deeds and actions.
text.8: This verse explains that for those who believe in Allah, affirm the truthfulness of the messengers, and perform righteous deeds, both those found in the books He has revealed and those conveyed by the messengers, refrain from all that He has forbidden, do not listen to songs, tales, and all kinds of sounds that can corrupt faith, diminish obedience, and lead to paths that incline towards evil deeds, Paradise full of delights is prepared. In it, there are all kinds of pleasures desired, such as food, drink, clothing, chambers, and so on.
text.9: They will abide therein forever. All of that is Allah's promise to His creation, which is certain to occur, and will not be denied in the slightest. On the other hand, severe is the punishment that He inflicts upon those who are sinful and hinder people from His path. Allah is All-Wise in managing and resolving all the affairs of His creation.
text.10:
This verse explains several signs and proofs of Allah's power found in this universe, namely:

1.  Creating the universe with all its contents, in the form of countless planets. These many planets are large spheres floating in vast space. In this verse, it is mentioned "without pillars as you see." From this statement, it can be understood that the sky has pillars, namely a force that supports it and functions as pillars, so that the planets do not fall apart. Only knowledgeable people can see these strong pillars with their inner knowledge.

2.  Allah created mountains on the surface of the earth so that the earth is stable, does not shake, so that humans, animals, and plants can live peacefully on it. The mountain is as if it were a stake that can strengthen the surface of the earth, like the towering masts of a ship, which can stabilize the ship sailing and anchoring in the middle of the ocean, so that it does not sway. In addition, mountains also have other benefits for humans, including regulating the distribution and channeling of rainwater poured from the sky, so that the water remains on the surface of the earth even during the dry season. There are many more benefits of mountains for humans and other creatures of Allah.

3.  Allah created animals that cannot be counted in number and type, shape and color, from the large to the small, so that they are not visible to the eye. All the animals that are created have benefits and advantages. Sometimes humans, because they do not know the benefits and uses of these animals, kill and exterminate them, so that without realizing it, damage occurs in this nature. However, Allah knows with certainty the number, type, color, use, and benefits of all the animals He created.

4.  Allah sends down rain from the sky. The rain comes from the clouds that He drives to a certain place, then turns into rain that wets the surface of the earth. With the rainwater, all kinds of plants grow with various kinds, with beautiful colors and many benefits.

According to scientists, the sky, with its apparent reality, as far as the eye can see, does not have a single pillar supporting it. Human logic requires a supporting pillar so that it does not collapse. However, Allah, with His power, is able to do things beyond the reach of human logic. Humans and all creatures living on earth are under the earth's gravitational system (attraction force). Thus, they can stably do their work on earth, not floating in the air.

When leaving the earth and entering a weightless realm, humans also know that there all objects become floating and weightless, including humans themselves. It is easy for Allah to make anything according to His will, including making the sky "light" and weightless so that pillars are not needed to support it. But can it also be considered that the force fields that exist in this universe are "virtual pillars" that are not visible to the eye?
text.11:
In this verse, Allah affirms that what is mentioned in the previous verse is Allah's creation, both in the heavens and on earth. Nothing is associated with Allah in creating all those creatures, and nothing has power over them except Allah. All necessities for the survival of those creatures, where they can live and where they will die, as well as the benefits and harms that those creatures can cause, are all known, regulated, and maintained by Allah.

Then Allah challenges those who associate partners with Him, "Show Me what the idols and statues that you worship have created. Have those statues done anything that can be believed to make them gods besides Me?"

At the end of this verse, it is explained that those who worship gods other than Allah are ignorant, misguided, and follow their desires. They are unjust to themselves, so they are afflicted with torment because of following their desires.
text.12:
This verse explains that Allah bestowed wisdom upon Luqman, namely a refined feeling, intellect, and wisdom that could lead him to true knowledge and the right path towards eternal happiness. Therefore, he was grateful to Allah who had given him that blessing. This indicates that the knowledge and teachings conveyed by Luqman did not originate from revelation sent down to him by Allah, but solely based on the knowledge and wisdom that Allah had bestowed upon him.

Based on the narration of Ibn Abi Shaybah, Ahmad, Ibn Abi Dunya, Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, Ibn Mundhir, and Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn 'Abbas, Luqman was a servant/slave and carpenter from Abyssinia (Habashah). Most scholars say that Luqman was a wise and insightful man, and not a prophet.

Many narrations explain the origins of Luqman, and these narrations are inconsistent with each other. Said bin Musayyab said that Luqman came from Sudan, south of Egypt. Zamakhsyari and Ibn Ishaq said that Luqman was a descendant of the Children of Israel and one of the grandchildren of Azar, the father of Ibrahim (Abraham). According to this opinion, Luqman lived before the arrival of Prophet Daud (David). According to al-Waqidi, he was one of the qadhi (judges) of the Children of Israel. There is also a narration that explains that Luqman was only a very pious man (wali), not a prophet.

Regardless of all the above narrations, whether Luqman was a prophet or not, whether he was Sudanese or a descendant of the Children of Israel, what is clear and believed is that Luqman was a servant of Allah who had been granted wisdom, possessed a correct creed, understood the fundamentals of Allah's religion, and knew noble morals. His name is mentioned in the Qur'an as one who always devoted himself to Him.

As a sign that Luqman was a servant of Allah who was always obedient to Him, feeling His greatness and power in the universe, was his attitude of always being grateful to Allah. He felt very dependent on Allah's blessings and felt that he had received wisdom from Him.

According to a narration from Ibn 'Umar, he once heard the Messenger of Allah say, "Luqman was not a prophet, but he was a servant who did much tafakur (reflection), he loved Allah, so Allah loved him too."

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that whoever is grateful to Allah, means he is grateful for his own benefit. Because Allah will bestow upon him a great reward for his gratitude. Allah says:

"Whoever is grateful - then he is grateful for [the benefit of] himself; and whoever denies - then indeed, my Lord is Free of need and Generous." (an-Naml/27:40)

Sufyan bin Uyainah said, "Whoever performs the five daily prayers means he is grateful to Allah, and whoever prays for his parents after every prayer, he has been grateful to them."

Those who deny Allah's blessings and are not grateful to Him mean that they have wronged themselves, because Allah will not give them a reward but will even punish them with a painful punishment. Allah Himself does not need the gratitude of His servants because the gratitude of His servants will not give Him any benefit, nor will it increase His glory. He is All-Powerful and Praiseworthy.
text.13:
Allah reminds the Messenger of the advice that Luqman once gave to his son when he was teaching him. The advice was, "O my son, do not associate anything with Allah. Indeed, associating [others] with Allah is a great injustice."

Associating partners with Allah is considered injustice because it means placing something in the wrong place, namely equating something that bestows blessings and favors with something that cannot provide all of that. Equating Allah as the source of blessings and favors with idols that cannot do anything is an act of injustice. This act is considered a great injustice because what is equated with creatures that cannot do anything is Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the universe, to whom all creatures should serve and enslave themselves.

Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn Mas'ud that when the verse was revealed:

"Those who believe and do not mix their belief with injustice - for them is security, and they are [rightly] guided." (al-An'am/6: 82)

unease arose among the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). They felt that it was very difficult to maintain faith without mixing it with injustice. They then said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), "Who among us does not mix faith with injustice?" Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) replied, "That is not what is meant. Have you not heard the words of Luqman, 'O my son, do not associate anything with Allah. Indeed, associating [others] with Allah is a great injustice.'"

From this verse, it is understood that among the obligations of a father to his children is to give advice and lessons, so that his children can take the right path and avoid error. This is in accordance with Allah's saying:

"O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones..." (at-Tahrim/66: 6)

If we pay attention to the structure of the sentences in this verse, we can conclude that Luqman forbade his son from associating partners with God. This prohibition is something that Luqman should indeed convey to his son because associating partners with Allah is the greatest sin.

Children are the successors of their parents. The ideals that parents have not achieved during their life in the world are expected to be achieved by their children. Likewise, the beliefs held by their parents, in addition to noble character, children are expected to inherit and possess all the values ​​followed by their father in the future. Luqman has carried out a very important task for his son, by conveying the true religion and noble character. The way Luqman conveys this message must be emulated by every parent who claims to be a Muslim.
text.14:
In this verse, Allah commands mankind to be devoted to their parents by striving to fulfill their commands and realize their wishes. In other verses, Allah also commands the same, His words:

And your Lord has decreed that you not worship except Him, and to parents, good treatment. (al-Isra'/17: 23)

The reasons why a child is commanded to be good to their mother are:

1. The mother carries a child until it is born. During that pregnancy, the mother patiently endures considerable suffering, starting in the first months, then the pregnancy becomes heavier and heavier, and the mother becomes weaker, until she gives birth. Her strength only recovers after the postpartum period.

2. The mother breastfeeds her child until the age of two years. The mother experiences much suffering and hardship in breastfeeding her child. Only Allah knows all that suffering.

In this verse, only the reasons why a child must obey and be good to their mother are mentioned, not why a child must obey and be good to their father. This shows that the difficulties and suffering of the mother in carrying, caring for, and educating her child are far greater than the suffering experienced by the father in caring for his child. This suffering is not only in the form of sacrificing part of her life to care for her child, but also physical and spiritual suffering. A mother also provides essential substances in her body for her child's food while the child is still a fetus in the womb.

After being born into the world, the child is then breastfed for a period of two years (primarily). Breast milk (ASI) also consists of essential substances in the mother's blood, which are offered with love for the child to suck. In breast milk, there are all kinds of substances needed for the physical and spiritual growth of the child, and to prevent all kinds of diseases. These substances are not found in cow's milk. Therefore, cow's milk and the like will not be of the same quality as breast milk. All kinds of powdered milk or canned milk are not of the same quality as breast milk.

A mother is strongly encouraged to breastfeed her child with breast milk. Do not replace it with powdered milk, except in very compelling situations. Getting breast milk from the mother is the child's right, and breastfeeding the child is an obligation that Allah has placed on the mother.

In this verse, Allah only mentions the reasons why humans must obey and be good to their mother. The Prophet saw himself commanded that a child should prioritize being good to his mother over his father, as explained in the hadith:

From Bahz bin Hakim, from his father, from his grandfather, he said, "I asked, O Messenger of Allah, to whom am I obligated to be devoted?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "To your mother." I asked, "Then to whom?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "To your mother." I asked, "Then to whom else?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "To your mother." I asked, "Then to whom else?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "To your father. Then to the closest relative, then the closest relative." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and at-Tirmidzi)

As for the duration of breastfeeding, the Qur'an commands that a mother breastfeed her child for a maximum of two years, as explained in this verse, with His words, "and weaning him within two years." In another verse, Allah determines the period for breastfeeding the child to be two years. Allah says:

Mothers may breastfeed their children two complete years for whoever wishes to complete the nursing [period]. (al-Baqarah/2: 233)

His word again:

And his gestation and weaning [period] is thirty months. (al-Ahqaf/46: 15)

The meaning of the verse above is that the time needed for a mother to carry her child is at least six months, and the breastfeeding period is twenty-four months or two years. If the two are added together, the number 30 months will be found.

The Qur'an teaches that a mother should breastfeed her child for two years. In verse 233 of Surah al-Baqarah, it is explained that the two-year breastfeeding period is for a mother who wants to breastfeed her child perfectly. This means that if there is an obstacle, or the two-year period feels very heavy, it can be reduced.

The two-year breastfeeding period contains another wisdom, namely to space out births. By implementing this natural arrangement, a mother will only give birth at the earliest once every three years, or slightly less. Because during breastfeeding, a woman is generally difficult to get pregnant again.

Then Allah explains that the meaning of "doing good" in this verse is that humans should always be grateful for every blessing that has been bestowed upon them, and also be grateful to their parents because they raised, cared for, and educated and were responsible for them, from the womb until they grew up and were able to stand on their own. The period of raising children is a difficult time because parents bear all kinds of hardships and suffering, both in guarding and in trying to find a livelihood for their children.

Parents in this verse are mentioned in general, without distinguishing between Muslim and non-Muslim parents. Therefore, it can be understood that a child is obliged to be good to his parents, whether his parents are Muslim or non-Muslim.

In addition to what is mentioned above, there are still several things that require a child to respect and be good to his parents, including:

1. Mothers and fathers have poured out their love for their children. This love and affection is manifested in various forms, including raising, educating, guarding, and fulfilling the wishes of their children. These non-binding efforts are carried out without expecting any reward from their children, except that they will later become children who are useful for religion, nation, and country.

2. Children are the apple of their parents' eye and heart, as mentioned in a narration that the Messenger of Allah said, "Fatimah is the apple of my eye."

3. From the womb, then born into the world until adulthood, the needs for food, drink, clothing, and other necessities of children are borne by their parents.

In other words, it can be expressed that the greatest blessing received by a human being is the blessing from Allah, then the blessing received from his parents. That is why Allah places the obligation to be good to both parents, after the obligation to worship Him.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns that humans will return to Him, not to anyone else. At that time, He will give fair retribution to His servants. Good deeds will be rewarded with multiplied rewards in the form of paradise, while evil deeds will be rewarded with the torment of hell.
text.15:
It is narrated that this verse was revealed in connection with Sa'ad bin Abi Waqqash, who said, "When I embraced Islam, my mother swore that she would not eat or drink until I abandoned the religion of Islam. For that, on the first day, I begged her to eat and drink, but she refused and remained steadfast in her stance. On the second day, I also begged her to eat and drink, but she still remained steadfast in her stance. On the third day, I begged her to eat and drink, but she still refused. Therefore, I said to her, 'By Allah, even if you had a hundred souls and they left one by one in front of me until you died, I would not abandon the religion I have embraced.' After my mother saw my conviction and strength of resolve, she finally agreed to eat."

From the reason for the revelation of this verse, it can be understood that Sa'ad was not sinful for not following his mother's wishes to return to the religion of shirk (polytheism). This ruling also applies to all followers of the Prophet Muhammad, who are not allowed to obey their parents in following the religion of shirk and other sinful acts.

This verse explains that in certain matters, a child is forbidden from obeying his parents if they command him to associate partners with Allah, which he himself does not know that Allah has partners, because indeed there are no partners for Him. As far as human knowledge goes, Allah has no partners. Because according to instinct, humans must believe in the Oneness of God.

Furthermore, Allah commands that a child should still be kind to both parents in worldly matters, such as respecting, pleasing them, and providing them with decent clothing and shelter, even if they force him to associate partners with God or commit other sins.

In another verse, it is warned that a child is obligated to say good words to his parents. Never act or say words that offend them, even just the word "ugh". Allah says:

¦therefore do not say to them [so much as], "uff," (al-Isra'/17: 23)

At the end of this verse, Muslims are commanded to follow the path of those who turn to Allah, the One and Only God, and not to follow the path of those who associate partners with Him with creation. Then this verse is concluded with a warning from Allah that only to Him will mankind return, and He will inform them of what they have done during their life in the world.
text.16:
Luqman advised his son to perform good deeds because whatever humans do, from the largest to the smallest, the visible and the invisible, the seen and the hidden, whether in the heavens or on earth, is certainly known to Allah. Therefore, Allah will surely give a reward commensurate with the deeds of that person. Good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise, while evil deeds and sins will be rewarded with Hell. Allah's knowledge encompasses everything, and nothing escapes His knowledge, not even the slightest thing.

Allah then describes in His word about the weighing of human deeds:

And We will place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection, so no soul will be treated unjustly at all. (al-Anbiya'/21: 47)
text.17:
In this verse, Luqman bequeathed the following to his son:

a. Always establish prayer in the best possible way, so that it is pleasing to Allah. If the prayer performed is pleasing to Allah, then abominable and evil deeds can be prevented, the soul becomes pure, there is no anxiety for that person, and they will not be saddened if afflicted by trials, and they will feel closer to their Lord.

The Prophet (saw) said:

Worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then indeed He sees you. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

b. Strive to invite people to do good deeds that are pleasing to Allah, strive to purify the soul and achieve success, and prevent them from committing sinful deeds. Allah says:

Successful indeed is the one who purifies it (the soul), and failed indeed is the one who corrupts it. (ash-Shams/91: 9-10)

c. Always be patient and steadfast in the face of all kinds of trials that befall you, as a result of inviting people to do good and abandon evil deeds, whether the trials are in the form of pleasure and splendor, or in the form of misery and suffering.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that Allah commands the three things mentioned above because they are works that are of great benefit to those who do them and provide benefit in this world and the hereafter.
text.18:
This verse explains the continuation of Luqman's advice to his son, namely that his son should have good character, by:

1. Never be arrogant and haughty, boastful, and look down on others. The signs of a person who is arrogant and haughty are:

-When walking and meeting other people, he turns his face away, unwilling to greet or show a friendly attitude.

-Walking with an arrogant attitude, as if he is the one in power and the most honorable. Allah says:

And do not walk upon the earth exultantly. Indeed, you will never tear the earth [open], and you will never reach the mountains in height. (al-Isra'/17: 37)

In a hadith, the Messenger of Allah said:

Do not hate each other, do not turn your backs on each other, and do not envy each other, and be servants of Allah who are brothers. It is not permissible for a Muslim to isolate himself (not be kind) from his friend for more than three days. (Narrated by Malik from Anas bin Malik)

2. Walk naturally, not artificially and appearing arrogant or haughty, and be gentle in speaking, so that those who see and hear it feel happy and calm. Speaking with a harsh, arrogant, and haughty attitude is forbidden by Allah because that kind of speech is unpleasant to hear, hurts the heart and ears. Allah likens it to the sound of a donkey, which is unpleasant to hear.

Yahya bin Jabir ath-tha'i narrated from Gudhaif bin haris, he said, "I sat near 'Abdullah bin 'Amr bin al-'ash, then I heard him say, 'Indeed, the grave will speak to the person buried in it, it says, 'O son of Adam, what has deceived you, so that you enter my hole? Do you not know that I am the house where you are alone? Do you not know that I am a dark place? Do you not know that I am the house of truth? What has deceived you so that you enter my hole? Indeed, when you were alive, you were arrogant."

Simple or natural in walking and speaking does not mean walking with your head bowed and speaking softly. However, the intention is to walk and speak politely and gently, so that people feel happy to see it. As for walking with a brave and natural attitude, and speaking firmly which shows a strong stance, it is not forbidden by religion.

According to a narration from 'Aisyah r.a. that she saw a man walking with his head bowed weakly, as if he had lost his physical strength, so she asked, "Why is that person walking too weakly and slowly?" Someone answered, "He is a very knowledgeable fuqaha." Hearing that answer, 'Aisyah said, "Umar was the leader of the fuqaha, but when he walked, he walked with a brave attitude, when he spoke, he spoke a little loudly, and when he hit, his blow was very hard."

text.20:
This verse reminds mankind by asking whether they do not pay attention to the signs of Allah's oneness and power in this vast universe. Do they not observe that it is Allah who has subjected everything in this universe for them, so that they can benefit from it. He is the One who made the sun shine, so that the day becomes bright. The sunlight can grow plants that will become food for humans.

The moon and stars were made to shine, which can illuminate the dark night and serve as guides for ships sailing the seas. He sends down rain that wets the earth and fertilizes plants, and its water is for the drinking of humans and animals, and some of that water is stored in the ground as preparation for the dry season. He creates various kinds of minerals, natural gas, and so on, all of which can be utilized by humans. No one can count the blessings of Allah that He has bestowed upon mankind.

From Ibn 'Abbas r.a., "I asked the Prophet saw, 'O Messenger of Allah, what is the meaning of outward blessings?' He replied, 'A person's good character. And inward blessings are that he is given guidance to the religion of Islam.'" (Narrated by al-Baihaqi)

Some people are of the opinion that adh-dhahirah is health and noble character, and al-bathinah is knowledge and intellect. Others interpret adh-dhahirah as all of Allah's visible blessings, such as wealth, splendor, beauty, and obedience, while al-bathinah is knowledge about Allah, good conviction, knowledge about the true essence of life, and so on. Although there are differences about the meaning of adh-dhahirah and al-bathinah, it can be concluded that both are blessings bestowed by Allah upon mankind and can be felt by them.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns that even though He has bestowed countless blessings upon mankind, there are still many people who deny and reject those blessings, such as Nadhar bin haris, Ubay bin Khalaf, and others. They refuted the evidence presented by the Qur'an and the call of the Prophet without being based on knowledge, true arguments, and revelation and books revealed by Allah.
text.21:
This verse explains that the disbelievers mentioned in the previous verse can no longer be expected to believe because they are extremely ungrateful and their minds have been covered by blind imitation of their ancestors. Therefore, they no longer pay attention to the arguments presented. Their nature and attitude are described by Allah in this verse by saying, "And when it is said to them who deny the Oneness of Allah, 'Follow what Allah has revealed to His Messenger,' they answer, 'We follow what our fathers taught us, and they have taught us the true religion and good provisions for us.'"

At the end of this verse, it is explained that those polytheists continue to follow the religion of their ancestors, even though their elders were without knowledge and never received guidance. This shows that in matters of belief, they no longer use their minds, but have been enslaved by their desires (hawa nafsu). Such desires are breathed and planted by Satan into the hearts of the disbelievers, so that they will not be able to see the truth. As a result of that action, they will be plunged into the torment of Hell in the Hereafter.
text.22:
This verse explains that those who worship Allah, submit and humble themselves to Him, are sincere and earnest in carrying out His commands, and abandon all acts of disobedience and evil, have grasped the firmest handhold.

The meaning of the word "ihsan" in this verse is to worship Allah earnestly, so that one feels as if one is directly facing Him, as explained by the hadith, when the Prophet (saw) was asked by Jibril:

"Tell me about ihsan." The Prophet (saw) replied, "That you worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then indeed He sees you." (Narrated by Muslim from 'Umar)

Allah likens those who perform "ihsan" who truly believe in Him, obediently carry out His commands, and stop His prohibitions, to a mountain climber who uses a rope bundled at the point of holding. He does not need to worry because he is using a rope with strong and firm knots to hold on to. There is not the slightest worry in his heart about falling.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that all creatures return to Allah alone. Therefore, He alone gives good rewards to those who trust in Him by giving good recompense as well.
text.23: This verse is a consolation to the Prophet (saw) and the companions who felt saddened by the attitudes and behaviors of the polytheists towards them. It is as if Allah is saying, "O Prophet, do not grieve because of their disbelief. For your duty is only to convey My religion to them, not to make them believe. They will all return to Me on the Day of Judgment, and then they will be informed of everything they did during their lives in the world. I will conduct a fair assessment of it because I know everything that is contained within their hearts."
text.24:
This verse explains to the disbelievers that they are only given a brief and temporary enjoyment of life. During that short time, they can utilize the blessings provided by Allah and taste the pleasures of life. However, that temporary pleasure is meaningless compared to the pleasures of the hereafter. That temporary pleasure will disappear, as if they never experienced it, when they face the painful torment in the hellfire later. This is reinforced by another saying of Allah:

Say, "Indeed, those who invent falsehood about Allah will not succeed." [For them is] enjoyment in this world, then to Us is their return; then We will make them taste the severe punishment because they used to disbelieve. (Yunus/10: 69-70)
text.25:
This verse states the ignorance and fanaticism of the polytheists towards the religion of their ancestors. The proof of their ignorance is stated by Allah, "And if you ask those polytheists, O Muhammad, about who created the heavens and the earth, they will surely answer that the One who created both and what is in them is Allah."

This admission of theirs is a true admission, and they will be forced to answer thus, because it is indeed very clear that the One who made this universe is Allah. Based on that admission, they should worship and devote themselves to Allah alone, because He is the Lord who deserves to be worshipped. However, their actions and attitudes are contrary to their admission because they associate Allah with something that does not give benefit and does not give harm.

Then Allah teaches His Messenger that when the polytheists answer thus, then say, "All praise is due to Allah." Because with such an answer, they have acknowledged their mistake in worshipping what should not be worshipped.

Allah also warns that if they do deeds that are contrary to their own admission, then this is because most of the polytheists do not know who deserves human praise and gratitude. In the admission of the polytheists, there is a reality that even though they deny the Prophet Muhammad, because they believe that the universe is the creation of God, in essence, they acknowledge the prophethood. According to logic and reason, Allah has created this universe, including humans, of course, He will not just let it go. God will certainly send messengers to give His *taufiq* and *hidayah* to humans.
text.26:
To Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and everything within them; there is no other, for He is the One who created them. He is the One who regulates, guards, maintains, and determines the end of their existence. He acts according to what He wills. Therefore, He is worthy of praise and glorification, and it is fitting to offer gratitude to Him. He does not need anything from His creation.

From this verse, it can be understood that according to Islam, wealth belongs to Allah. Humans are only lent it and permitted to utilize it, according to the provisions of the religion. Therefore, Allah could forcibly take all of humanity's possessions. However, because Allah knows that humans possess the characteristic of stinginess, He does not do that. Allah only takes a portion of the wealth that is obligatory to be given as *zakat*. In this case, the *waliyyul-amri* (the governing authority) has the right to take, even forcibly if necessary, the *zakat* funds that are with the Muslims, to be channeled in the way of Allah.
text.27:
It is narrated that when the Messenger of Allah was still in Mecca, the following verse was revealed:

"And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about the soul. Say, "The soul is of the affair of my Lord. And mankind have not been given of knowledge except a little." (al-Isra'/17: 85)

When he migrated to Medina, the Messenger of Allah came to the Jewish rabbis. They said, "O Muhammad, it has reached us that you said, 'and mankind have not been given of knowledge except a little.' Do you mean us by that statement, or your people?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "I mean everyone." They said, "Have you not read in the book revealed to you that the Torah was revealed to us, and in it is knowledge of everything?" The Messenger of Allah said, "The knowledge in the Torah is little, compared to the knowledge of Allah, and indeed Allah has revealed to me something, which if you practice, will surely benefit you." They said, "O Muhammad, why do you say that, when you say, 'and whoever is given wisdom has certainly been given much good.' How can little knowledge and much good be combined in something?" Then Allah revealed this verse as an answer.

This verse explains the vastness of Allah's knowledge. This is illustrated by the fact that if all the trees on earth were made into pens to record the knowledge of Allah, and all the sea water was made into ink, then added with seven times that amount, the words of Allah would still not be finished being written. In another verse, Allah says:

Say, "If the sea were ink for [writing] the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement." (al-Kahf/18: 109)

The meaning of "kalimat Allah" (words of Allah) in this verse is very broad, including Allah's power, the reality of everything, Allah's decrees and words, His knowledge, and all kinds of His creations. In addition, it also includes the creation of the heavens and the earth with all kinds of things in them, from the large to the subtle, from the largest animal to thousands of the most subtle bacteria. The diverse plants, the animals in the sky with all their rules, and many more that are countless, are all included in the kalimat Allah.

In this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is severe in His demands. All His will and decisions will surely be carried out, and He is All-Wise in all His actions.
text.28:
This verse explains that making anything is easy for Allah. Whether it is making something large, small, complex, or making something in a small quantity, it is all the same to Allah. Likewise, resurrecting people from their graves on the Day of Judgment is easy for Allah. Resurrecting all of humanity for Allah is no different than resurrecting just one person. Nothing is difficult for Him. If Allah wills something to happen, it is enough for Him to say, "Kun" (Be!), and it will be as He wills. Allah says:

"Indeed, His command is when He intends a thing, He says to it, "Be," and it is." (Yasin/36: 82)

And Allah says:

"And Our command is but one word, like a glance of the eye." (al-Qamar/54: 50)

At the end of this verse, Allah states that He hears all the words of His servants and is All-Seeing of all their deeds.
text.29:
In this verse, Allah commands mankind to observe and contemplate His power. He causes the night to enter into the day, and causes the day to enter into the night. The meaning is that Allah takes a portion of the night's time and adds it to the day's time, resulting in the lengthening of the day, while the night becomes shorter, but a full day and night remains 24 hours. This occurs during the summer season. Meanwhile, Allah also takes a portion of the day's time and inserts it into the night, thus lengthening the night, and conversely, shortening the day. This occurs during the winter season.

Such occurrences are very clearly visible and experienced by the inhabitants of countries located in regions that have four seasons in a year, namely summer, autumn, winter, and spring, which are the North Temperate and South Temperate zones. As for countries located in the equatorial region, there are only two seasons in a year, namely the dry season and the rainy season. And at times when the night is longer than the day, or the day is longer than the night, the difference is not felt because the difference in the length of the night or day is not significant.

The occurrence of four seasons in a year, and the occurrence of the day being longer than the night or vice versa in the North Temperate and South Temperate zones, is because Allah tilted the earth's position at a latitude of 22 Â½ degrees, as is known in Astronomy (Ilmu Falak). All of this contains great wisdom.

Allah also subjected the sun and the moon for the benefit of mankind. Sunlight is a lamp that illuminates humans during the day, so they can work and strive. Sunlight also fertilizes plants, creates wind and clouds, and various other uses. Likewise, the moon and its light, and its varying shapes, have many uses for humans, but only a small portion of these uses are known.

The moon and the sun revolve in their respective orbits, according to the provisions that Allah has determined, until the time that He has appointed. When that appointed time comes, the heavens and the earth will be rolled up, as Allah says:

(Remember) the Day when We will fold the heaven like the folding of a [written] sheet. (al-Anbiya'/21: 104)

At the end of this verse, it is stated that Allah knows all the deeds that His servants have done, whether they are good deeds or bad deeds. Nothing escapes His knowledge. Allah will give them just recompense.
text.30:
This verse explains that Allah's purpose in showing His signs to mankind is to provide them with strong evidence and proof that mankind is obligated to worship Him, and that He alone is worthy of worship. Worshipping or serving anything other than Allah is a false action because everything besides Him is transient and impermanent. He is the All-Sufficient and needs nothing else, while all creatures are utterly dependent on His blessings.

Finally, this verse affirms that Allah is the Most High, transcending all things, the Most Great, and controlling all things. Everything submits and obeys Him.

(31) In this verse, Allah commands mankind to observe the signs of His power and greatness on earth, saying, "Do you not see, O Muhammad, the ships sailing through the sea, connecting distant lands?" Through this connection, the inhabitants of one land will come to know the inhabitants of another. The needs and requirements of the people that are not available in their own land can be obtained and transported by ships from other lands, such as food, clothing, medicine, jewelry, machinery, and so on. With these ships, it is as if the relationship between nations and countries today is getting closer.

Ships were first made by Prophet Noah according to Allah's command in the mission to save the believers, along with a number of pairs of animals (read more in Surah Hud/11:40). However, with human thinking ability, ship technology has developed. Ships are not only made of wood but have even developed using metal. Although lately, with the development of material technology, humans have been able to "mix" available materials into materials that are lighter, more compact, easily formed, strong, weather-resistant, and impact-resistant. Iron, which should sink because the density of the metal is much greater than the density of water, can float on the surface of the water through the use of science and technology (iptek), namely by applying Archimedes' law (physics). In essence, the laws of physics are Allah's decrees. Allah's decrees that can be felt for their benefits in human life. That is the true blessing of Allah.

All that Allah has explained are clear proofs of His power and greatness for those who are patient in facing all kinds of trials and difficulties, and for those who are grateful for the blessings of Allah that have been bestowed upon them. A sign of a person being grateful to Allah is by expressing gratitude in the form of words or deeds when receiving that blessing.

Asy-Sya'bi said, "Patience is a part of faith, gratitude is a part of faith, and certainty is the whole of faith. Do you not pay attention to Allah's words found at the end of this verse and His words: "wa fi al-ardhi ayatun li al-muqinin" (and on the earth are signs for those who are certain) and the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him):

Faith has two parts, namely a part in patience and a part in gratitude. (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Anas)
text.31:
This verse explains that the purpose of Allah showing His signs of power to mankind is to be a strong argument and proof for them that mankind is obligated to worship Him and that He alone is worthy of being worshipped. Worshipping or serving other than Allah is a false action because everything other than Him is perishable, not eternal. He is All-Sufficient and does not need others, while all creatures are very dependent on His blessings.

Finally, this verse affirms that Allah is the Most High, surpassing all things, the Most Great, and controlling all things. All are submissive and obedient to Him.
text.32:

Asy-Sya'bi said, "Patience is a part of faith, gratitude is a part of faith, and certainty is the whole of faith. Do you not pay attention to Allah's words at the end of this verse and His words: "wa fi al-ardhi ayatun li al-muqinin" (and on the earth are signs for those who have certainty) and the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him):

Faith has two parts, namely a part in patience and a part in gratitude. (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Anas)
text.33:
This verse explains the characteristics of polytheists by depicting them: "When the polytheists, idol worshippers and deity venerators, sail into the middle of the ocean, suddenly a large wave comes and slams their ark left and right, and they feel that they will not be saved, but will die swallowed by the waves, then at that moment they return to their fitrah, by praying to the One God with the utmost sincerity. At such a time they are convinced that nothing can save them except Allah alone, as Pharaoh once did in the moments when he was about to drown in the sea."

After Allah accepts their prayer and saves them from the fury of the waves, only some of them continue to acknowledge the Oneness of Allah, while the others return to associating partners with God.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that those who deny His verses and return to associating partners with God are those whose lives are full of deceit and corruption, and who deny the blessings of Allah.

(33) In this verse, Allah commands mankind to carry out His commands and to stay away from things that are forbidden. The Lord who created mankind and created the heavens and the earth with all its contents for their benefit. Mankind should fear the day when a terrible disaster occurs, when no one can save himself from that disaster. At that time, a father will not be able to help his son, nor will a son be able to help his father, because all matters at that time are in the hands of Allah. Each person is responsible for all the deeds he has done. They bear their own sins. Only the good deeds they have done during their life in the world can save mankind from that disaster.

Allah warns that His promise to resurrect mankind from the grave is something that will truly happen and a truth that cannot be doubted in the slightest. Therefore, let mankind never be deceived by the pleasures of life in the world and all the pleasures in it, so that they strive and spend all the time they have to obtain and enjoy worldly pleasures. As a result, there is no more time to worship Allah, and to do good deeds and *amal saleh*. Whereas the life of the hereafter is the real life, the eternal and better life.

Likewise, Allah warns mankind about the deception of Satan, who is always looking for opportunities to deceive mankind. Satan makes the life of this world beautiful in their eyes, so that they forget the task that Allah has placed upon them as *khalifatullah fil ardh* (creatures who are given the task of prospering the earth).
text.34:
In this verse, Allah explains five unseen matters that only He knows, namely:

1. Only Allah knows when the Day of Judgment will come. No creature knows, not even the angels, even though the angels are the creatures closest to Him. This is also unknown to the prophets who were sent.

"None can reveal its time but He." (al-A'raf/7: 187)

2. Only Allah sends down rain. He determines when, where, and how much water will be poured down. No one can know this determination.

3. Only Allah can know for sure what is in a woman's womb, whether it is defective or perfect, and when it will be born.

4. Only He knows for sure what a person will do tomorrow. Even though humans can plan what they will do, it is all just a plan. If Allah wills, the work will be done. However, if He does not will it, it is not difficult for Him to prevent its implementation.

5. A person does not know where he will die. Whether on land, at sea, or in the air. Whether in this country or in another country. Only Allah can know for sure.

It is narrated from Ibn Mundhir from 'Ikrimah that a man named al-Waris bin 'Amr bin Harisah came to the Prophet saw, he asked, "O Muhammad, when will the Day of Judgment come? Our land is dry, when will it become fertile? Indeed, I left my wife pregnant, when will she give birth? I know what I am doing now, so what will I do tomorrow? I know where I was born, so where will I die?" As an answer, this verse was revealed.

Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah saw said:

"The keys to the unseen are five: 'Indeed, with Allah [alone] is knowledge of the Hour. He sends down the rain and knows what is in the wombs. And no soul perceives what it will earn tomorrow, and no soul perceives in what land it will die. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Umar)
